metadata.title: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)  Communication Disorders
anatomical location body part affected: Central nervous system, including lower motor neurons and upper motor neurons of the corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts, anterior motor horn cells, and bulbar motor nuclei(2,34)
description: ALS is the most common progressive motor neuron disease.(2,3) Patients with ALS present with both upper motor neuron (UMN) and lower motor neuron (LMN) dysfunction(3)
Two forms of ALS –Spinal/limb form of ALS, in which initial symptom is weakness in a limb(1) –Bulbar form of ALS, in which initial symptom is difficulty speaking or swallowing(1,55)

presentation signs and symptoms: Presentation will vary according to the location and extent of motor neuron loss, the combined effects of LMN and UMN loss, how the disease initially manifests, the progression of the disease, and which body region(s) is/are affected(4)  –Symptoms of UMN involvement -Spasticity(3) -Loss of dexterity(3) -Stiffness(3) -Weakness due to spasticity(3) -Loss of voluntary motor control(3) –Symptoms of LMN involvement -Weakness(3) -Weakness initially presents in a limb, the bulbar muscles, or the respiratory muscles(3) -Fasciculations (muscle twitches)(3) -Muscle atrophy(3) -Muscle cramps(3) –Symptoms of bulbar involvement -Dysarthria(3) -Bulbar dysfunction disrupts the normal movements of the lips, jaw, and face necessary for articulation(61) -Dysphagia(3) -Sialorrhea (drooling)(3) -For detailed information on assessment and treatment of sialorrhea, see Clinical Review…Drooling ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708632 -Aspiration(3) -Pseudobulbar affect (laughter or crying unrelated to mood)(3) -If the bulbar system is involved at the onset, initial symptoms often include articulation and voice deficits, problems with chewing and swallowing, and difficulty performing movements of the face and tongue(3,55) –Symptoms of cognitive impairment -Behavioral dysfunction(3) -Executive dysfunction(3) -Patients with ALS who have accompanying cognitive impairments often have symptoms of frontotemporal dementia.(3,5,50) (For detailed information on frontotemporal dementia, see Clinical Review…Dementia, Frontotemporal ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708948) –Speech symptoms -Patients can sometimes produce intelligible speech long after the onset of bulbar ALS symptoms(6) -Intelligibility often decreases rapidly during the middle phases of ALS.(6) Reduced speech intelligibility appears to be associated with loss of articulatory control of the tongue, lip, and jaw muscles(59) -Slow speech rate is common in patients with ALS.(48) When a patient’s speech rate decreases to 60% of normal, or approximately 100 words per minute, a precipitous decline in intelligibility can be expected(6) -Patients are likely to exhibit a mixed flaccid/spastic dysarthria(4,7) -Spastic dysarthria leads to forced-sounding  voice.(4) For detailed information on spastic dysarthria, see Clinical Review…Dysarthria, Spastic ; CINAHL Topic ID Number:T708753 -Flaccid dysarthria leads to a voice that is hoarse or breathy.(4) For detailed information on flaccid dysarthria, see Clinical Review…Dysarthria, Flaccid ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708850 -As ALS progresses, patients often become unable to produce intelligible speech (anarthria) and often require an augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) system(3,4) -Pharyngeal weakness results in hypernasal voice quality and/or nasal air emission(4,7) -Research indicates that reduced strength of the tongue and loss of lingual-alveolar  contact pressure is related to impaired speech intelligibility(60)  -Palatal weakness and fasciculation might be observed during examination(7) –Dysphagia symptoms(4) -Early signs and symptoms of dysphagia might include drooling, wet voice, coughing during or after drinking thin liquids, nasal regurgitation, and requiring an excessive amount of time to finish a meal(3) -Difficulty with food manipulation inside the mouth(4) -Difficulty moving food into the esophagus(4) -Impaired swallow(4) -Choking(4) -Slowed eating(4) -Poor caloric/nutritional intake(4) -For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in patients with ALS, see Clinical Review… Dysphagia: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708986

Although traditionally it was believed that the sensory system is typically not affected, current research with electrophysiological examination has revealed abnormal sensory nerve conduction in 23% of patients with ALS(4,8) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Depression is common in patients with ALS(2,53,54) –Depression can negatively impact the results of communication assessments and make communication impairments (especially those related to cognition) appear worse than they actually are(12) –Depressive symptoms in ALS are associated with reduced quality of life(54)
Precautions will vary according to the individual patient and the severity of accompanying language, cognitive, and motor symptoms
During a speech-language  evaluation, it is of utmost importance to be aware of a patient’s pain tolerance and level of frustration
Patients with ALS might display changes in speech and voice (reduced phonatory control and vocal limits) that can be measured objectively before such changes are noticed perceptually(13)

causes: 90–95%  of cases are sporadic and of unknown etiology(1,2,47)
5–10%  of cases are familial and appear to be inherited(1,9)
pathogenesis: Etiology largely unknown in sporadic cases of ALS(1,2,9)–Research suggests that a multifaceted interaction of pathogenic cellular mechanisms result in sporadic ALS, including:(10)-Genetic factors(10)-Some research suggests that most degenerative neurological diseases, including ALS, are related to complex proteinmisfolding disorders.(47) Studies have suggested that ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases are associated withabnormalities of the TDP-43  protein(47)-Excitotoxicity resulting from excessive glutamate activity in the brain and spinal cord with subsequent calcium influx toneurons/neuronal death(10)-Oxidative stress with accumulation of reactive oxygen species(10)-Mitochondrial dysfunction(10)-Impaired axonal transport(10)-Neurofilament aggregation(10)-Protein aggregation causing cytoplasmic inclusions(10)-Inflammatory dysfunction with abnormal microglial and dendritic cell activation(10)-Deficits in neurotrophic factors with dysfunction of signaling pathways resulting in early cell apoptosis(10)

In familial ALS, an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern is most common; however, autosomal recessive, X-linked,  andmitochondrial inheritance patterns have been reported(10)–Age of onset generally is earlier in familial ALS and progression is more rapid(10)–Juvenile ALS is a rare form of familial ALS with onset before age 25; this type of ALS has a much slower progression,with the ability to ambulate into midlife; many of these patients have a normal lifespan(10)
risk factors: Age; most common age at onset is 40–60  years (mean age of onset 58)(10,11)
Sex; males more commonly affected than females (ratio of 1.5:1)(10)
Having a family member with the familial form of ALS is a risk factor for that type of ALS(9)
Possible geographic disease clusters in Guam, western New Guinea, Japan’s Kii Peninsula(10,34)

overall contraindications precautions: The speech-language  pathologist (SLP) should carefully review all medical records before evaluating or treating a patient with ALS A patient’s cultural and linguistic background should be considered to determine the appropriateness of examination and/or therapy materials(12) The patient’s caregiver/family should be involved in all assessment and treatment procedures

contraindications precautions to examina: Depression is common in patients with ALS(2,53,54) –Depression can negatively impact the results of communication assessments and make communication impairments (especially those related to cognition) appear worse than they actually are(12) –Depressive symptoms in ALS are associated with reduced quality of life(54)
Precautions will vary according to the individual patient and the severity of accompanying language, cognitive, and motor symptoms
During a speech-language  evaluation, it is of utmost importance to be aware of a patient’s pain tolerance and level of frustration
Patients with ALS might display changes in speech and voice (reduced phonatory control and vocal limits) that can be measured objectively before such changes are noticed perceptually(13)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Refer to neurological testing and physician reports for information on the specific type of ALS, presenting symptoms, and medical treatment/recommendations

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Tracheotomy is often performed to place a tracheostomy tube for patients who elect long-term  ventilator support or if the muscles of respiration are significantly affected(3,5) Feeding tubes might be required when a patient is no longer able to swallow safely(3) Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV),such as continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), is common in patients with ALS as a result of respiratory insufficiency.(14,52) NIPPV prolongs survival in patients with ALS.(52) If a patient becomes unable to tolerate NIPPV or it is no longer effective, invasive ventilation with tracheostomy might be considered(4)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? There is no cure for ALS; however, researchers continue to search for drugs that will slow the progression of ALS. Currently, one drug, riluzole (Rilutek), has been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for slowing the progression of ALS(2,3,11) Pharmaceutical management of sialorrhea might include glycopyrrolate or amitriptyline.(14)Sialorrhea might also be addressed by transuranic neurectomy, salivary duct ligation, and parotid gland irradiation or injections of botulinum toxin into the salivary glands(3) Medications prescribed to help control emotional lability include amitriptyline and fluvoxamine(8) Medications such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors or benzodiazepines are often prescribed for patients with anxiety and depression(52)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  A diagnosis of ALS is made following a physical examination of the neurologic, musculoskeletal, and cardiorespiratory systems. Electrodiagnostic tools can also be used. Neuroimaging (primarily MRI) and clinical laboratory studies should be completed in order to rule out other diseases or conditions(3)

Authors of a systematic review of studies testing the diagnostic accuracy of the Awaji criteria (initially proposed in 2008) for diagnosis of ALS versus the El Escorial criteria found that the Awaji criteria allowed for significantly earlier diagnosis and entry into clinical trials. Both sets of criteria are for use with electrodiagnostics(46)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had speech-language  therapy, occupational therapy, or physical therapy for this or for other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors -Are there times of day when the patient has more/less difficulty communicating? -Are there specific situations in which it is more/less difficult for the patient to communicate? -Is the patient aware of communication difficulties? Is the patient frustrated by communication difficulties? -Does the patient speak more than one language? If so, does the patient and/or caregiver note more/less difficulty speaking in one particular language?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Patient will display symptoms of UMN and LMN involvement(2) -Aspiration (including silent aspiration)(3,8) -Behavioral dysfunction(3) -Dysarthria(3) -Dysphagia(3) -Executive dysfunction(3) -Fasciculations(3) -Frontotemporal dementia(3) -Loss of dexterity(3) -Loss of voluntary motor control(3) -Muscle atrophy(3) -Muscle cramps(3) -Pseudobulbar affect (laughter or crying unrelated to mood)(3) -Sialorrhea (drooling)(3) -Spasticity(3) -Stiffness(3) -Weakness(3)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if  pain   is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., depression, dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document any respiratory difficulties the patient is experiencing as well as use of supplemental oxygen, NIPPV or mechanical ventilation, and tracheostomy tube -Respiratory muscles often are affected in patients with ALS; respiratory status usually becomes more impaired as the disease progresses(3) -Dysphagia and aspiration can lead to pneumonia(3) -Tracheostomy and ventilator support often become necessary in the final stages of the disease(3,4,5,14) Inquire about symptoms of depression and refer to a neuropsychologist, clinical psychologist, or psychiatrist when signs are present (e.g., loss of interest in daily activities, problems sleeping, feelings of sadness and hopelessness) -Assess quality of life in all patients with ALS. Examples of quality of life scales are the ALS Functional Rating ScaleRevised  (ALSFRS-R),  the McGill QoL (MQoL), the ALS Specific Quality of LifeRevised  (ALSSQOL-R),  and the Communicative Effectiveness Index (CETI)(57,58) -In a study conducted in Portugal with 27 patients with ALS, researchers found that use of AAC in early stages of ALS was associated with improved quality of life(58) -The presence of dysarthria and dysphagia, which commonly occur together in patients with ALS,has been found to significantly reduce quality of life(51) -Depression is common in patients with ALS(2,49) -Many depression and psychological scales have been used to assess patients with aphasia, which might be a symptom of frontotemporal dementia (the type of dementia associated with ALS). The SLP can collaborate with the psychologist to -Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) (mild aphasia)(15) -Depression Intensity Scale Circles (DISC) (moderate aphasia)(15) -Stroke Aphasic Depression Questionnaire (severe aphasia  to be completed by caregiver)(15) -Visual Analogue Self-Esteem  Scale(16)Note hearing ability -Does the patient have difficulty hearing in the quiet treatment environment? -Does the patient ask for frequent repetitions of words? -Does the patient have a known hearing loss? If so, does he or she wear hearing aids or a cochlear implant? Left, right, or bilateral? -It may be appropriate to recommend audiology consult for patients with suspected hearing loss Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Does patient have a history of cognitive and/or communication impairments?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient, family, and/or caregiver about other problems the patient is experiencing, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient, family, and/or caregiver about other symptoms the patient is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: -Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -Does the patient participate in language-based  recreational activities? -Does the patient work or attend school? -Does the patient regularly use a computer/telephone?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: -Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -Note if patient wears hearing aids, glasses, or has a cochlear implant and determine if equipment is in working order -Note any use of wheelchair, walker, or communication devices -Document if the patient uses any adaptive equipment to communicate (e.g., pen/paper or high-tech  AAC device)Document with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members)

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) Patients with ALS should be assessed every 3 to 6 months for changes in speech and language abilities(52)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Does patient display good strength when pushing against a tongue blade? Is patient able to count from 1 to 100 and maintain good muscle strength?(29)Diadochokinetic rates (i.e., alternating motion rates and sequential motion rates) typically are reduced in puh, puh, puh? Can patient perform sequential motion tasks, such as puh, tuh, kuh, quickly and precisely with one breath of air?(29)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: What is the ROM of the patient’s articulators? Is patient able to open his or her jaw? Extend and hold articulators in various positions?(29)  -In a study conducted in the United States with 11 patients with ALS, researchers found that, compared to healthy speakers, the tongue movements of speakers with ALS exhibited a restricted range of motion for coupling movements (quick movements that the tongue makes to accomplish fast articulatory changes in connected speech) as well as overall reduced lingual speed. These changes were associated with declines in speech intelligibility(43)Is patient able to coordinate the speed, strength, range, direction, and timing of speech movements?(29)Is patient able to hold a position with his or her articulators? Is patient able to sustain production of smooth, steady vowels?(29)What are the characteristics of the patient’s muscle tone in his or her articulators? Does muscle tone affect patient’s ability to adequately adduct his or her vocal folds?(29)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Screening for vision and hearing should always precede screening for cognitive and/or language impairments. An audiologist should check for impacted cerumen prior to a pure-tone  audiometric screening and word-recognition testing(12)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosisan assessment rating functional performance with subtests in speech, swallowing, and lower and upper extremity function(8)Tests that assess pragmatic and communication skills used in daily living (e.g., calling for(30) An assessment, rating, and inventory of the patient’s functional communication skills (e.g., sign, nonverbal, augmentative)(31) Assessment of functional communicationsocial communication; communication of basic needs; reading, writing, and number concepts; and daily planning(32) Measure of change in functional communicative ability. Assesses four domains Life Skills, and Social Needs
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Speech and language examination (including reading)Common characteristics of speech in patients with ALS include abnormal speech rate, hypernasality, reduced vocal volume, and prosodic disturbances(47)Articulation skills can be assessed using standardized assessments or by obtaining and analyzing speech samples. Initial sounds affected by ALS are typically those produced by the tongue tip contacting the alveolar ridge, including /t, d, l/.(47) Phonetic feature analysis can be completed on single-word  productions(20)(21) Purpose is to quantify single-word  intelligibility, sentence intelligibility, and speaking rate for adult and adolescent speakers (22) Purpose is to diagnose dysarthria and to provide differentialreflexes, respiration, lips, palate, laryngeal, tongue, intelligibility, and influencing factors (e.g., hearing, mood, language). Norms are provided for patients aged 12–97  years(23) Purpose is to evaluate children and adults with dysarthria. Includes 21 quantitative tasks and 15 rating-scale  tasks that are used to determine the severity of a patient’s dysarthria and make recommendations for treatmentAs ALS progresses, patients will experience a decline in their speech rate and intelligibility. This decline may continue until a person is completely unintelligible. Researchers have documented that once a patient’s speaking rate drops to 100 words per minute, intelligibility will significantly decrease. Careful monitoring of speech rate will enable the SLP, patient, and family/caregiver to make the necessary preparations for use of AAC(24)Complete informal and standardized assessments of receptive and expressive language. Language skills of patients with ALS can be impaired (sometimes subtly) at any stage of the disease, even in the absence of overt cognitive dysfunction.(25) In a study conducted in the United Kingdom with 51 patients with ALS and 35 healthy controls, researchers found that language impairment was evident in 43% of the patients with ALS and that executive functioning was impaired in 31% of these patients(45) -For detailed information about evaluation of language abilities and aphasia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic –VoiceCan include measurements of nasal airflow, nasal airway resistance, velopharyngeal timing and movement, and velopharyngeal orifice size(20) -Velopharyngeal status in patients with ALS can be determined with good accuracy through the use of local sensors in a nasal cannula at the anterior nares connected to a device that measures nasal ram pressure(26)Acoustic signal analysis provides quantitative information related to perceptual judgments and can be used to confirm phonetic error patterns. A computerized signal processing system can be used to study the F2 slope, F1-F2  vowel space calculations, and acoustic energy. These three acoustic measures are known to be sensitive to changes in vowel and consonant articulation in speakers with dysarthria. Over the course of treatment, acoustic signal analysis can be used to quantify and measure changes(27)Abnormalities of breath patterns and respiratory incompetence often compromise speech production in patients with ALS.(47) Breath pattern observations should note irregular breathing rates; the absence of normal inhalation-exhalation  patterns; the initiation of speaking at atypical points in the respiratory cycle; the interruption of speech from sudden, forced inspiratory/expiratory sighs; exaggerated respiratory maneuvers; running out of air before inhaling; and breathing at syntactically inappropriate locations in the utterance(20)A brief reading assessment in patients with ALS is appropriate as reading ability should factor into the choice of AAC method
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: Fasciculations in the tongue typically are one of the earliest clinical markers of ALS.(47) For patients presenting for reduced speech intelligibility without a known diagnosis, it is essential to communicate to the ordering physician when tongue fasciculations are observed during the patient’s evaluation. Other common findings in patients with ALS are drooling, hypernasal voice quality/nasal emission, and loss of lingual range of motion.(47) It is important to examine the speech structures and musculature at rest and during movement as well as during both speech and nonspeech tasks.(28) For motor speech disorders, such as flaccid dysarthria, the following six items should be carefully
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Patients with frontotemporal dementia associated with ALS will exhibit cognitive decline; executive functioning impairments; difficulties with planning, organization, and concept abstraction; and personality and behavior changes. Patients with ALS in whom frontotemporal dementia has not been diagnosed might also exhibit cognitive impairments such as difficulties with verbal fluency, language comprehension, memory, abstract reasoning, and generalized impairments in intellectual function.(4) Refer to neuropsychological and cognitive evaluations to assist in informing course of treatment and providing a prognosis for therapyPatients with frontotemporal dementia associated with ALS sometimes exhibit deficits in cognitive and language functioning that interact to make functional communication difficult -A patient’s inability to attend to, perceive, organize, and remember information will impact receptive and expressive language skills -Difficulties with problem solving and executive functioning negatively affect functional communication; it is important that the SLP assess ways in which cognitive-linguistic  difficulties affect the patient’s ability to communicate in social, academic, and/or vocational situations -A cognitive-linguistic  assessment should also consider how various communication tasks can be modified in order to support a patient’s functional communication(17) –Researchers who conducted a study in the United States with 41 patients with ALS found that cognitive impairments in ALS were related to cortical thinning in the prefrontal and parietal cortex(18) –In a study conducted in the United States with 25 patients with ALS, researchers found that patients with poor scores on a letter fluency test had a reduced ratio of N-acetylaspartate  (NAA) to creatine-phosphocreatinine  (Cr) in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex as seen on magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS)(44)
relevant tests and measures.aac assessment: Due to the high prevalence of severe communication impairments among patients with ALS, many will eventually require the use of an AAC system.(19)When assessing a patient’s need for an AAC system, it is important to –Valid assessment -Assess the patient’s existing opportunities for communication and look for ways to enhance the quality and quantity of these opportunities in order to increase the patient’s participation in meaningful daily activities(19) -Assess the patient’s communication opportunities in a variety of settings and with a variety of communication partners(19) -Assess the patient’s communication needs with both familiar and unfamiliar communication partners(19) –Capability assessment -Assess the patient’s cognitive, sensory, perceptual, social, motor, reading/literacy, writing, and linguistic skills(19) -Because motor abilities become so impaired in ALS, AAC may involve the use of microswitches that are operated by only one finger or even eye-tracking computer systems.(56) Review current reports from the physician as well as physical and occupational therapy to determine the patient’s current gross and fine motor capabilities –Feature matching -Based upon assessment results, identify which AAC system will best meet the patient’s needs(19) –Identifying barriers to participation -Identify communication barriers encountered by the patient and devise interventions to overcome these barriers.(19) For detailed information on AAC assessment and intervention with individuals with ALS, see Clinical Review…Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis ; CINAHL Topic ID Number
relevant tests and measures.swallow examination: Complete dysphagia assessment as indicated –For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in patients with ALS, see Clinical Review…Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) , referenced above
relevant tests and measures.tracheostomy examination: Tracheostomy and ventilator support often become necessary in the final stages of the disease.(3,4,5,14) If present, assess tracheostomy tube and document date of placement, current respiratory status, and use ofT709084. For detailed information on assessment of a tracheostomy tube and use of a speaking valve, see Clinical Review…Passy-Muir  Tracheostomy & Ventilator Swallowing and SpeakingT708919

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Inform patient and family/caregivers of the potential for falls and educate about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies
SLPs should consider the patient’s level of frustration and level of awareness during assessment and treatment so as not to offend or upset him or her

To ensure relevance and appropriateness of treatment programs, decisions about goals and course of therapy should be made in collaboration with the patient, caregivers, and other healthcare professionals.(33) It is highly recommended that family members be involved in the rehabilitation process as much as possible
SLPs should carefully consider the patient’s stamina and medical status before beginning therapy
Cultural background, language preference, and patient interests must be considered when planning treatment goals and activities
Precautions will vary according to the individual patient and the severity of accompanying language, cognitive, behavioral, and/or motor symptoms
As with an evaluation, it is important to thoroughly review a patient’s medical records prior to any treatment

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
Patients with ALS are at risk for aspiration and penetration of oral intake. Inform the patient and family/caregivers of potential aspiration risks and educate about strategies when appropriate

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: A fully certified and licensed SLP will be able to identify speech, language, cognitive-linguistic,  and swallowing impairments associated with ALS. The patient, caregivers, and SLP will determine the most appropriate goals for therapy at the time of evaluation as well as consider future needs as the disease progresses
assessment plan of care.rule out: ALS is diagnosed if both UMN and LMN involvement is evident. The patient’s physician or neurologist will rule out diseases involving only UMNs (e.g., progressive muscular atrophy, spinal muscular atrophy), only LMNs (e.g., primary lateral sclerosis, multiple sclerosis), or only the bulbar system (e.g., progressive bulbar palsy, myasthenia gravis)(3)
prognosis: Researchers in the United States conducted a retrospective study with 625 family members/caregivers of individuals with ALS examining communication methods during the last 6 months of life and found that as the end of life approached all modes of communication decreased, including natural speech, writing, gestures, and use of AAC devices. Additionally, the study indicated that immediately prior to death (1–2days), approximately one fourth of the patients with ALS were unable to communicate in any way; however, another one fourth of patients were still able to communicate with natural speech immediately prior to death(35)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: The focus of multidisciplinary treatment of ALS is maximization of the patient’s quality of life(8) The patient’s medical team should include a primary care physician, neurologist, physiatrist, and nurse(8) –Referrals to a pulmonologist, otolaryngologist, and/or gastroenterologist may be appropriate as the disease progresses(8) Referral to a physical therapist, occupational therapist, social worker, and nutritionist may be beneficial for improvement of the patient’s quality of life(8) Refer to respiratory therapy when signs of respiratory decline are present(2)
treatment summary: Treatment might initially occur on an outpatient basis, but patient may ultimately need to be placed in a nursing home or provided with hospice care(11)
Treatment involving comprehensive care provided using a multidisciplinary approach is optimal for patients with ALS(4)
SLPs treating patients with ALS need to work closely with a respiratory therapist because management of respiratory dysfunction is critical(2)

Literature on treating communication disorders associated with ALS focuses on three areas: the use of strategies to increase speech intelligibility, the use of a palatal lift prosthesis for patients with excessive air loss through the nasal passageway, and the use of AAC devices –Strategies to improve speech intelligibility in patients with dysarthria -Encourage patient to exaggerate articulation in order to increase speech intelligibility(3,4) -Encourage patient to use an appropriate rate of speech in order to increase intelligibility (slower if dysarthria has increased speech rate, faster if dysarthria has slowed speech rate)(3,4) -Encourage use of pausing and phrasing strategies to increase speech intelligibility(37)  -Modify the environment through means such as decreasing background noise(4) -For more information on the treatment of speech disorders in dysarthria associated with ALS, please see the Clinical Reviews on spastic dysarthria and flaccid dysarthria –Palatal lift prosthesis -Authors of a systematic review of speech interventions for patients with ALS found two studies examining palatal prostheses for patients with ALS, one retrospective study and one case study(38) -In the retrospective study authors found that the palatal lift moderately improved dysarthric speech in 84% of the patients for at least 6 months(38) -Patients also reported using less effort when speaking while wearing the prosthesis -In the case study of a 35-year-old  male with ALS exhibiting mild to moderate flaccid spastic dysarthria, the following was observed(37) -With the palatal lift in place, 71% of the man’s speech was intelligible on taped samples of words and sentences as compared to 16% without the lift -With the palatal lift in place, the patient’s production of fricatives occurred at higher intensity levels and with longer periods of duration -With the palatal lift in place, the patient displayed significantly less abnormal nasal airflow –AAC (For detailed information on AAC intervention for individuals with ALS, see Clinical Review…Augmentative and Alternative Communication: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis , referenced above) -As ALS progresses and speech becomes less intelligible, treatment will focus on providing the patient with an AAC device before he or she is completely unintelligible(6,24) -Eighty percent of patients with ALS will have significantly impaired speech during the course of the illness and will require AAC(39) -AAC might initially be a low-tech  device (e.g., writing board or pad and pen; alphabet board), eventually progressing to a high-tech  device (computers with voice synthesizers or single-switch,  scanning computerized communication systems; brain-computer  interface[BCI])(4) -In a study that involved a severely dysarthric German-speaking  patient with ALS, researchers in Germany examined the effect of visible vs. concealed alphabet board cues(40) -The patient’s rate of speech was 80 words/minute in spontaneous speech; however, he had sufficient arm movement to be able to simultaneously point to the first letter of each of the word(s) he said(40) -Twenty-two  German-speaking  listeners split into 2 groups were asked to first listen to the patient’s habitual speech through headphones; then, each group listened to cued speech and the listeners in group 1 were shown the first letter of the target word on a laptop screen; the listeners in group 2 were not given the first letter(40) -Overall, the visible letter cues significantly improved intelligibility when compared to the no cues condition; not all of the words were equally aided by letter cues, with higher frequency words resulting in the highest percentage of intelligibility(40) -Researchers are investigating the effectiveness of BCI AAA, an emerging technology, in improving communication in patients with ALS  (62,63,64) -BCI AAC uses EEG readings to allow the AAC user to access the AAC device and communicate(63) -In a pilot study with 42 subjects with ALS, 14 of the subjects were able to learn how to use BCI device, with the primary purpose being communication(63) -An AAC assessment is recommended once a patient’s speaking rate decreases to 125 words per minute, even if speech intelligibility is good at the time. This is due to the fact that speech intelligibility rapidly and significantly declines once a patient’s speaking rate is 55–70%  of average.(6,24,36) Speaking rate may be monitored from a distance through the use of a telephone and computer software programs in order to decrease the number of visits a patient must make to a clinic while ensuring a timely AAC assessment.(41) Authors of a systematic review on communication abilities in ALS emphasized the need for early assessment for and training in the use of AAC to maximize quality of life throughout disease progression(62) -Researchers in the United States conducted a study of 50 patients with ALS that revealed that 96% of participants accepted AAC technology either immediately or with some delay. Patients who accepted the devices immediately decided to purchase devices as soon as an AAC assessment was completed and began using the device as soon as  possible. Patients who had “delayed acceptance” either did not immediately schedule an AAC assessment or did not purchase a device immediately following the assessment. However, eventually patients in the delayed acceptance group did undergo an AAC assessment, purchase a device, and use it to communicate. The 2 patients who did not accept AAC devices exhibited symptoms of dementia and cognitive limitations that were cited as the reasons for their rejection of the technology(39) -Clinical practices that lead to favorable outcomes with AAC device use include:(39) -Patient/family are provided with information on the speech-language characteristics associated with ALS -Speech changes are monitored through ongoing contact with the patient so that the timing of interventions is optimal -Patient/family education is provided continuously -Researchers in the United States conducted a study of 45 patients with ALS that revealed that patients with primary bulbar ALS used their AAC devices for 25 months and patients with spinal (limb) ALS used their devices for an average of 34.2 months. The factors negatively impacting the duration of AAC use were: 1) patient was placed on sustained ventilator support, and 2) patient received “late” referrals for an AAC assessment (after the 125 words per minute guideline)(42)

Exercise: Authors of a systematic review of the literature on speech interventions for patients with ALS found only 2 case studies examining the efficacy of exercise for the oropharyngeal musculature; in both cases the dysarthria was worse after intervention(38)

Dysphagia management might include diet modifications and eventual placement of a feeding tube, although some controversy surrounds use of feeding tubes in these patients.(2,11) For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in patients with ALS, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) , referenced above .
